description:
ENTER A WORLD OF VICTORIAN HORROR!

In 19th-century Rome, ancient crypts have been discovered beneath the Capuchin tombs. Take on the role of a dauntless explorer and plunder these catacombs of their secrets and spoils. Build your catacomb as you go, seeking finds and surviving horrors. End your story before the evils of the catacomb devour you all!

IN TENEBRIS LUX is a game for 1-4 players ages 13 and up, and can be played in about 45 minutes to an hour. 
Players rush to explore and resolve personal quests, called narratives, before their opponents can resolve their own, or the dark catacombs close in on them, ending the game.

The game is played in turns, each broken into 3 Steps, with several Phases.

STEP 1: BREATHE The first Step adds Rooms to the Catacombs, by drawing them from a random pile. This builds up the game board out of playing card sized map pieces, or Rooms. This step also has a phase allowing Explorers to change their gear, referred to as Equipment or Finds… this is critical as these important items strengthen an Explorer so that they may deal with the dangers to come. Following phases allow an Explorer to adjust their card hand and play any non-room cards, if so desired.

STEP 2: SEEK The second step allows Explorers to actually explore and navigate through the Catacombs, or growing game board.  This dangerous course allows Explorers to search for new Finds and gear. More phases allow for adding extra Rooms, or cards, onto the board, moving around from card to card, and interacting with Room Cards in order to complete Naratives, or the game’s objectives. This is the Phase where Explorers are most at risk of stumbling upon Horrors, as they are actively exploring the Catacombs.

STEP 3: SURVIVE In Step 3 Horrors, the game’s many monsters in the dark, may attack your Explorer! Canny and brave Explorers may also strike out and attack each other in hopes of thwarting each other’s progress in pursuit of personal Narratives. This phase resolves each combat one by one, and adjusts health and loot bodies.

Basic combat is simple. As the attacker, role one of the game’s 14 included dice, and add it to your chosen Trait (Grit, Wit or Daring).  The Defender rolls one die and adds it to their same Trait, as they defend along the same lines as the incoming attack. Whichever result is highest wins.

The game’s “Combat Reference Card” will take players through any extra steps, notably the way in which rooms impact the outcomes with rolls in combat. Each Horror and Explorer features an affinity with different Room types, this gives an edge or disadvantage in combat. Be careful of the Room you land on, it will have dire consequences!

After each Step is resolved a player finishes their turn and, moving clockwise, the next player goes, and so on. The game is ended when one player completes their randomly drawn Narrative objective, all Explorers are killed, or the Doom Counter (the Game’s timer) has run its course, sending the catacombs crashing in on the hapless Explorers.

In Tenebris Lux comes with 13 Jumbo Explorer cards, 4 jumbo Combat and Turn Cycle reference cards, a full color rule book, 24 Horror cards, 18 Equipment cards, 21 Find cards, 12 Narrative cards, 32 Room cards, 3 Great Room Jumbo cards, one Jumbo Doom Counter card, 14 Dice, 13 Double Sided Explorer counters with 4 stands, and a counter for each Horror as well as many counters to help record progress for Narratives.

One month ago, Star-ship union find an asteroid with many historical remains near the SiTan galaxy. One after another, treasure-hunters arrive this ruin star and search the treasure by the loading of symbols on remains' wall.
Now, it's time for you to show up. Players take a role of treasure-hunters. following the guide of map and racing to the finish first.
In the Ruinstar, draft randomly map-cards forming the race track, namely the map in current game. Also, players will take their own meeples and put them on the origin of map. During the game, players draft cards on the center and play them from hands on the front of themselves, acting as a their own exploration-cards colunm. Then, that player can get some symbols on the cards played by him and may use these symbols for other actions,such as destroy others' exploration-cards column or extra advance his/her meeple.
It's the most important and interesting that how to prevent others' plan and use your own symbols for advance on the map with Combos.

Populations is an insanely addictive game about primitive fantasy races and their struggles to sort out who's land is who's!

Throughout the game, players will explore a vast and mysterious world in order to find useful resources and victory points. The various resources (i.e. stone, wood, textile) are used to grow population, build fantastic castles, and discover useful technologies.

Specifically, on a players turn, they may spend action points to increase and move their population around the map, and to build castles to secure lands. Additionally, players may always explore new lands by drawing new land tiles and adding them to the known world!

Depending on the number of players, a victory point goal is set at the beginning of the game. Once a player has achieved the preset goal on their turn, they win the game. Likewise, if a player eliminates all other players from the game, then they stand victorious!

This takes the elements of a JRPG and puts them into an epic co-op tabletop adventure game. Players explore on a mini-map, grinding away as they search for the set-piece encounters - large battles that make or break the players.

The game is set up in Acts, with each act being represented as a box of map tiles and encounters. Each act is meant to be played in a single sitting (1.5-2 hours), and then strung together into an epic 3-act story, concluding with a massive boss fight. That boss is defined by the earlier 3-acts and since the game features lots of different acts, there is lots of replay value.

During the game, players use a bag of tokens that represents their characters "stats." When players use various abilities, instead of rolling dice to check for success, they will draw tokens from their bag and check the various icons and runes to see if they succeed. As players level-up, they will swap in ever-more-impressive tokens.

These token bags are also used by the heroes' enemies. Get set on fire? Put a fire token in your bag and you'll be on-fire until you draw it out. Get poisoned? Put 3 Poison tokens into your bag taking damage each time one comes out until you find a heal poison potion, etc...

To win the game, players must battle through 3 acts and then a mega boss.

Description from the designer:

The year is 1492. It is Sunday. The old pope is dead and now the race is on for the election of the new pope. You’re one of the hopefuls in this election, however, not everyone is on your side… yet. But don’t worry, they’ll come around once you show them a little financial appreciation. After all, everyone has a vote, and everyone can be bought. And once the new pope is elected, the richest player wins—just like in real life.

The goal in Habeamus is to amass more money than the other players, while electing a new pope. Every player has one vote, and there are three non-player cardinals with a vote each as well. During their turns, players can place bribes face-down on the non-player cardinals in the middle of the playing field. These cardinals will vote for whomever promises the largest bribe when the vote starts.
Each player also has a vote that they can use for themselves, or sell to other players. Every player can make hidden or open bribe offers to other players. If, during the vote count, a player accepts an offer by another player, that bribe goes into their account. However, if they do not accept the offer, the player making the offer gets the bribe into their account. In this way, players will have to balance their offers to other players and make sure they themselves sell their vote for a good price. To shake things up a bit more, a player can increase the papal salary, or play actions to change the bribes already on offer.
Once all cards have been played, the votes are counted. If a pope is elected, he will receive a salary bonus into their account. Then, every player counts their money and the richest player wins.

A snowbound small village. It quietly approaches and sneaks into the innermost part of a villager's heart. When the night has come and everyone else is sleeping, it quietly wakes up. The brutal murderer wanders around the village and preys on honest villagers. Who is the heinous monster?

Rocca Monster is a hidden role/social deduction game for 3-6 players. Each player is dealt three villagers which are placed on the table in front of them. One of the villagers in the game is secretly the monster. All players close their eyes and count to ten, during which time the player with the monster card places a six sided die on a villager of their choice. After the count is finished all players open their eyes and see who was attacked in the night. That player rolls the die, and on a roll of 1-4, the villager on whom the die was placed is killed. On a roll of 5 or 6, the villager survives the attack. After the murder (or attempted murder) the players discuss who they think the monster is, and then use their voting cards to vote for which villager they want to accuse of being the monster. Once a single villager has the majority of votes their card is turned over and it is revealed whether they were the monster or not. If they were the monster then the other players win! If they were not the monster then their card is removed from the game and play continues. Another night attack occurs, followed by another round of discussion and voting. This cycle continues until either the monster successfully kills half the villagers (at which point the monster player wins the game), or until the players successfully identify the monster (at which point the monster player loses and everyone else wins).

Big Hero 6 is a "6 in 1" game - it has 32 cards which are used in six different games, based on classics children's card games.


     Action Game - Win by getting ride of your cards as soon as possible.
     Action Game Snap - Win by getting all the cards.
     Pairs Game - Win by collecting the most pairs.
     Double Pairs Game - Win by collecting the most double pairs.
     Donkey Game - Win by not having the "Donkey" card in your hand at the end of the game.
     Happy Families Game - Collect the most Happy Families.


First published as part of a collection of promotional card games for Morrison's Supermarkets in the UK.

Contents:
32 Playing cards
2 Rules cards

5ive: King's Court is a set-building game in which players take turns attempting to foil the plans of their rivals by completing their own royal court.

Players compete to complete a set of all five card types by completing each of five actions. Every action impacts another player, so strategy is critical. Simple errors in judgement could prevent you from completing your court, allowing another player to take control and win the game!

The main point of this game is to level up fast through game experience. In this fantasy-themed game, your Hero can go up 21 levels in a single game session!

Players customize the powers of their heroes though rapid leveling up — with every passing round, their heroes gain experience and grow in power.

Heroes use abilities, tons of items, skills, and spells against enemy units in order to defend the Realm and find the Ancient Artifact before it's too late!

Each player will develop their own Hero during the game. .


     There are also extra cards for a Players VS Player version of the game.


During the game:
Players may recruit new characters, take control of mines (which produce gold and resources for the Cities), and most importantly, defeat the enemy units which occupy the map and Dungeon.

Game-play:
On your turn, your Hero (Attack) rolls one dice (or more in higher Level) AND additional black dice for each enemy in your Location. If the number of your Hero rolled dice matches the number of a Item, Skill, Spell Card that your Hero owns, he gets the effect of that Card.
If the number of enemy rolled dice (black) matches the number on enemy Card, it deals damage to your Hero and gets the effect of own Card.

At the most of the time your Hero rolled die will trigger other Players Cards. Yes, a lot of cards may be activated by other Players rolls and the owner of the Card gains the effect.
After combat roll, your Hero may spend Experience points to get new Skill and Spell Cards, and spending gold for new Items (weapons, armors, items, scrolls).

END OF THE GAME
Lose: lost one of the main City OR lost all magic towers/mines OR  then Dungeon population reached the max.
Win:  find the ancient artifact in the Dungeon AND clear the main 3 Cities from the enemies.

Contains

Dice (36x): 

     d4 x15,
     d6 x10,
     d8 x5,
     d10 x3,
     d12 x2,
     d20


Cards (486x)

     Different Hero Cards: 16x
     Different Item cards: 82x + enemy Units rewards 148x
     Different Skill Cards: 156x
     Different Spell Cards: 74x
     Different Attachments Cards: 32x
     Different Enemy Units Cards: 114x 
     Different Locations Cards: 54x
     Different Event Cards: 46x


Large spell books Cards: 20x

Peril and plunder await your pirate crew in Firelock’s newest game, Scurvy Dice! In this highly competitive dice roller you will strive against other commanders in a ship of your own design to pillage the wealth of the East Indies and the other captains with whom you compete. Broadsides and boarding actions are just some of the exciting encounters you will face in your race to riches. You will need boldness, cunning and not a small amount of luck to best your opponents and conquer life at sea. Will fortune favor you? Find out, in Scurvy Dice!

Scurvy Dice is played over a series of rounds called treasure hunts. Players will roll their ship dice to build and refit their ships to battle their opponents and race to find the best treasure at parrot island - all while trying to avoid getting scurvy.

—description from the publisher

A storm has blown through the sleepy, fairy-tail hamlet of Ewetopia, releasing the sheep from their barns and now they’ve all congregated into a massive, mixed-up herd in the middle of the valley! Players step into the role of village farmers, who must use their feisty canine companions to help them herd back the lost flocks.

Ewetopia is charming, fast-paced, easily-to-learn, and hard-to-master. With warm, friendly graphics that have appeal for kids, it will also appeal to older audiences with it’s deceptively tactical game play: A strong denial game, board control, and a playing field that can change with every turn means Ewetopia enjoy plenty of play-time with old and young alike.

Players command their trusty dog around a 5x5 grid filled with tiles containing numerically ranked sheep, pushing rows and columns of them, adding the tiles that get pushed off the grid to their collection. The dogs are very fast and will always move at least 2 squares during their turn, so although they can be made to change direction after their 1st move, they can’t then move back into the square they just came from: Players will need to plan their turn to avoid collecting the wrong tiles or ending up out-of-position.

Opponents’ dogs can’t be pushed and will create obstacles on the board, but if this happens, or if a player wants to create a better move for themselves, fences can be built in the way of the charging sheep, diverting their path in a direction of the player's choice. Since these fences remain in the ground until the end of the game --and act the same for every player-- the result is a maze-like meadow where creative, zigzag moves aren’t just possible, but become the norm.

Adding to the brain-twisting mix are special tiles, including:
Motivating Bones: When collected, can be consumed at any time to “motivate” a dog to move an extra square. Useful to push your dog to get a rare sheep, or to force an opponent to make tough choice if their dog is in a bad position.
Wild Sheep: A mythical breed with technicolor wool, these sheep can count as any rank at the end of the game, making them especially versatile.
Wolves: A snarky, stenchy wolf-pack have sneakily donned sheep costumes in order to blend into the herd. Their own rank, having them at the end of the game will reduce your score by stinking up your other sheep’s wool.
Wood Carts: Contains enough lumber to build an additional fence on the board when traded in, and may be used immediately after being collected.

At the end of the game, points are awarded based on sizes of unbroken, numerical sequences AND sets of same-ranked sheep, allowing players to pursue different paths to victory if their original plans are foiled. Point values scale logarithmically with size, meaning a single big set or sequence will always be better than several smaller ones. After separating their sheep into the largest sets and/or sequences possible, totaling their values --and subtracting points for wolves-- the player with the highest score is the victor!

Idyllon was the crown jewel of Faerie Queen Nivarra’s kingdom... once upon a time. But after a great betrayal at the hands of Ancient Therha, this once great land has dissolved into formless void. While all of those who remember its beauty mourn this tremendous loss, you – the Guardians of the Four Winds – have vowed to restore Idyllon to its former glory.

Groves is a strategy game that combines worker placement with bag building. There are multiple worker types that a guardian can summon to reap the benefits of the land. Using any worker-type will gain you a land’s ability but using a worker that is elementally linked to that land type will also earn you an additional ability to edge you closer to gaining the crown. 
Playing in other players’ groves may also work to your advantage; however, although you will be able to gain the ability of the land, your sprits will end up in your opponents’ summoning bag. Can you build your grove and manage your pool of spirits to become the new Ruler of Idyllon?

Chemistry Fluxx is the elemental card game in which the rules are always changing. Use atoms and laboratory gear to match the current goal and win!

Chemistry Fluxx is the perfect compound of chance and skill in which you'll not only be playing with elements and molecules, but you'll also be learning about them!

Snappy Dressers cards show quirky and delightful animal characters dressed in the snappiest of outfits! Cards are beautifully designed with interesting animals like the sloth, panda, and fox — all dressed in funky, cool outfits. Players try to identify a match, such as types of animal, items of clothing, or the gifts in the characters' hands. Each card matches every other card in exactly one way!

Snappy Dressers includes ten different games to play with one deck of cards, ranging from speed recognition to sly strategy.

Description from the publisher:

Sedis is a “generic gaming device”. Much like dominoes or playing cards, Sedis can be used to play and create many different games.

Each Sedis set consists of 60 hexagonal tiles, which can be evenly divided among one to six players. The arrangement of pips and blanks are conducive to patterns and interpretations that can be used to guide each game. These two attributes – the congruent shape of the tiles and the dot patterns unique to each tile – open up a world of board configurations, mechanisms, and ways to play.

Sedis has many different game mechanics which form the backbone of games, including:

Aligning tiles and matching pips/blanks
Rotating tiles
Stacking tiles
“Battle’ mechanics
Trading
Betting/Gambling
Bluffing
Partnering/Communicating
Collaborating
Interpreting pips as numbers
Interpreting pips as Morse code
And more mechanics continued to be discovered

True Story is an adult party game where you use cards prompts to inspire stories of extraordinary experiences or legendary lies. One player draw a card, tells a story involving the prompt on the card, and the other players guess whether or not the story is true or false. If the majority of players guess incorrectly the storyteller keeps the card. Play continues until one player has three cards.

Dazzling gems are the focus of your quest in Sapphiro. Play your diamond tiles to capture rubies, emeralds, and other valuable jewels by matching colors and surrounding the gems. Be careful not to leave a quick or easy way for your opponents to do the same. Be the first to collect one jewel of each color to win.

Includes wooden game board, 100 wooden tiles, 30 gems and rules.

Fantasy Fantasy Football is an inventive card game in which you are the Oracle manager of a football team of powerful and gruesome fantasy creatures battling through a season of fantasy football. Go head-to-head against other Oracle managers and battle the elements, manage bye weeks, and use your team's magic powers wisely.

Developed by designers Daryl Andrews and J.R. Honeycutt with art by Rob Lundy, Fantasy Fantasy Football is a roster-building card game in which players must assemble and manage a team through a season full of unexpected challenges using players skills and magical abilities to win games.

In this 2-player game, players use the cards in their hand to manipulate a function that allows players to trade in their colored cubes for more/different colored cubes in order to complete the goals set out at the beginning of the game. Once a player completes 2 of the 3 goals available, they win!

RULES:
To start the game, shuffle the 5 goal cards and randomly draw 3 of them. Those will be the goals for this game. The other 2 cards can be returned to the box.

Take the 1 Red cube "left" card and the 2 Yellow cubes "right" card from the deck and place them on the table. This is the starting function. Shuffle the rest of the cards and deal three to each player. Then give each player 3 red cubes. The player who was most recently in a math class will go second.

Turns:
Each turn, the current player MUST do the following things
- Play only one card to either side of the equation. 
- Perform the equation if they have the cubes on the left side to trade for the cubes on the right side from the supply. If they do not have the necessary cubes, they MUST take 1 red cube from the supply. 
- Draw one card from the draw pile.
(Play passes to the next player)

As soon as a player meets the requirements for one of the goals, the MUST trade those cubes into the supply and take that goal card. The first player to complete 2 of the 3 goal cards wins the game.

If the draw pile is exhausted, take the top two equation cards off and leave them on the table. Then you can shuffle the remaining cards to reform the draw pile.

If using the function causes a player to trade for a resource that has been exhausted, they do not get that resource and they do not take a red cube.

In this pirate game you have to find the chest which is hiding Jack Pott's treasure and after getting it be the first to make it to the canoe to win the game. For playing the game you need a free app that guided you through the whole game.

When it's your turn you roll the dice within the app and walk with your pirate figure the eyes number on a symbol on the game board. Depending on what figure your move ends you interact with the app which tells you what happens next or what you have to do. The game board shows a pirate ship which is devided in different parts. In each part is a treasure chest which maybe hides the treasure of Jack Pott.

The app uses augmented reality to scan the game board and it shows animations of the different characters which guided through the game

Grimdark Future is a single-page miniatures game set in a war-torn sci-fi future, which is played using 28mm miniatures. The game mechanics are designed to be easy to learn but hard to master, bringing engaging battles for new players and veterans alike.

It helps to remember that the "u" in Monster-Pups is pronounced like "ooooo" as that gives you a clue as to what this game's about. Yes, each player controls a monster that needs to use the toilet to do its business and drop a load, specifically a crystal that is placed underneath the monster.

Will the business happen, though? You place the monster on one of the toilets on the game board, use the stick end of the plunger to turn the wheel, and (maybe) a hole opens in the game board underneath the toilet. Listen for the plop! If you hear it, you can use the plunger to pick up one of your face-down tokens. With luck, you reveal a full roll of toilet paper to clean up after yourself. Whoever first finds three rolls wins!

SanremoN is a collectible card game. The deck consists of 40 downloadable cards. It celebrates 67 years of events and characters of Sanremo's Festival, setting them in a fantasy universe.

(The Sanremo Music Festival, or "Festival della canzone italiana di Sanremo", is a popular Italian song contest and awards ceremony. It is held annually in the city of Sanremo, Liguria, Italy.)

PURPOSE OF THE GAME: Being able to bring your opponent's life points to 0

HOW TO PLAY

It is played exclusively in two (1 Vs 1) and with a single deck of cards. The two players (Challenger A and Challenger B), after having shuffled the deck, draw 5 cards each.

The remaining cards remain available to Challengers who at the end of each round of play will draw one or more cards, depending on how many will they play, so you always have 5 cards. Each Challenger has 5000 Life Points to start.

In the first round, the Challenger A plays his first card, chosen among the 5 in their possession. The Challenger A is in the process attack, then the ATK (Attack) points of the card played will be those to be taken into account. The Opponent B, vice versa, is located in defense phase, and then play one of 5 cards in his hands, considering the DEF (Defense) points associated with it. If the ATK points of the opponent A will exceed DEF points of the opponent B, the Challenger to win the turn and the difference between ATK of A and B will be the DEF points to be subtracted to the Opponent's Life Points B. If the ATK points are equal to or lower than DEF points opponent, no Life Point will be subtracted from the Challenger B.

At the end of the round, played cards are collected in a new deck (the discard pile), and the two Challengers will fish from the draw pile as many cards as they were played before moving in round next. He will fish for the first Challenger will play in the Attack phase (in our case, it is for the Challenger B).

This continues round after round, until the the deck runs out. Then all the cards collected in the discard pile will be reshuffled and put back into play. Repeat for 5 times at most.

The winner will be the one who will manage to bring the Life Points of the opponent to 0, or the one who at the end of the 5th phase of the game has higher Life Points.

"For our friend and her new beginning..."

Balloon is a colorful game dedicated to friendship. Balloon features a color-friendly Cards and peaceful feelings with a sky background and lots of balloon!

Balloon has 2 modes of gameplay; party mode and couple mode. Party Mode is the easier and more fun mode of the game, where players need to make a balloon party merrier by adding confetti (flip Balloon Cards from clear side to confetti side) and by doing so they also sabotaging other players in a fun way. Meanwhile, in Couple Mode, players are required to use strategy to make sure they can fill their board faster or get higher Victory Points.

On both Party Mode and Couple Mode, winners are determined by most Victory Points, but how they acquire it is different. On Party Mode, Victory Points are distributed at random but on Couple Mode are based on how they perform on their player board.

There are one unique way to end the game, each time a player trade their resource to a Balloon Card, one resource has to be discarded, if there are 5 cards discarded with same color, the game immediately ends and Victory Points counted!

You seek to be elected to the head of Portyl, a medieval city composed of different guilds more or less powerful that will have to be converted to your cause in order to recover their voices. The election takes place in three rounds, with a count of votes in each round. At the end of the third round, the player having recovered the most votes will be appointed to the head of the city and will win the game.

In the 1990s, a small band of freedom fighting hackers team up to take down an evil corporation. They meet anonymously over computer networks to conceal their identities, but there's a problem -- one of them might be a corporate spy!

Dark Web is a game of hidden player roles and pushing your luck for 3-6 players, comprised of 128 cards. Search the servers for precious data files to incriminate the Moore-Ally-Good Corporation, but be careful who you trust as you may not all be on the same side.

The goal of the game is to download enough data files after 4 rounds to expose the corporation for what it is. On your turn you may play any action scripts in your hand, then decide if you want to bank your points or stay in and draw a card. But be wary of drawing a lock, as too many locks will cause your connection to be shut down and all the data you've found to be lost.

For IT players, do whatever it takes to stop the hackers. But be careful of revealing yourself too early, as once you do the hackers can work around you!

Gran juego de estrategia y conquista feudal.

A game of strategy and feudal conquest.
Roll and move to buy properties and build castles. You can buy castles from other players buying battle cards. If you lose your last coin, you are out of the game. The last player with money is the winner.

Gaia Project is a new game in the line of Terra Mystica. As in the original Terra Mystica, fourteen different factions live on seven different kinds of planets, and factions are bound to their own home planets, so to develop and grow, they must terraform neighboring planets into their home environments in competition with the other groups. In addition, Gaia planets can be used by all factions for colonization, and Transdimensional planets can be changed into Gaia planets.

All factions can improve their skills in six different areas of development: Terraforming, Navigation, Artificial Intelligence, Gaiaforming, Economy, Research; leading to advanced technology and special bonuses. To do all of that, each group has special skills and abilities.

The playing area is made of ten sectors, allowing a variable set-up and thus an even bigger replay value than its predecessor Terra Mystica. A two-player game is hosted on seven sectors.

—description from the publisher

To boldly roll where no dice have rolled before.

Dice Trek: A Space Battle in a Tin is light and fast 2 player duel, in which you will be trying to be 'last ship floating'. You will collect power and damage your opponent's mother ship by pushing and pulling two custom dice on a five card space battlefield, by deploying cards with units of various strength and influencing both dice simultaneously most of the time.

Designed for 2016 Mint Tin Design Contest

Best Overall Design - 8th
Most Innovative Mechanic - 9th
Best Theme - 8th
Best Artwork & Graphic Design - 3rd

Guest Judge: Caroline Berg - Top 3 Picks
2nd pick
  "Dice Trek: A Space Battle in a Tin, while I'm not a person for two-player games, I couldn't resist the theme. The game is more than just Star Trek: The Dice Game - it mixes in many Sci-Fi tropes, creating a feeling of nostalgic Sci-Fi action. The rulebook is well done, covering all the information the players need, and the graphic design is top notch."

Description from the publisher:

The decision to invade The Marianas (of which Saipan is a part) was not an easy one. General MacArthur still favored the more westerly route through the Philippines and had support amongst the Joint Chiefs of Staff. It took several conferences and nearly a year before the decision was made. There were several reasons that the Americans finally decided to invade the Marianas: Firstly, it was the most direct route to Japan, Secondly, they could base B29 bombers there which could bomb Tokyo, Thirdly, Saipan would be the first piece of prewar Japanese soil taken during the war. Lastly, the American planners hoped that they could draw the Japanese fleet into a decisive engagement. With all these reasons, a battle for the Marianas was inevitable.

On 15th June 1944 71,000 American Marines and Infantry attempted to make the plan work. 32,000 dug-in Japanese attempted to stop them.

Saipan – The Bloody Rock will be the first game to utilize the new Company Scale System (CSS) by Adam Starkweather and will come on 2 maps. This will be your chance to experience a full-on naval invasion as Amtracs and DUKWs head towards the emplaced forces of Imperial Japan.

The game will come with 4 scenarios and 2 campaign games:

Dog-Day – The first day of the Invasion. It is 8 turns long and fought on a single map. An excellent introduction to both the system and the game.

First Week in Hell – The first week of the invasion and the capture of Aslito airfield. This scenario is 56 turns long and is played on a single map. For the space but not time challenged players among you.

Death Valley – This scenario covers a single day of the fighting and concentrates on the American attempt to capture Mount Tapotchau and the area that became know as Death Valley. 8 turns long and a single map. An excellent large battle you can play over one sitting.

Shattered Jewels - This scenario covers a single day of fighting and revolves around the largest Banzai attack of the war. Thousands of Japanese attack the 105th Regiment near the town of Tanapag. Variable length but usually 4-5 turns.

The Battle for Saipan – The full historical campaign from 15th June- 9th July (224 Turns). This game covers the full fight for Saipan in 1944, from the first invasion at Charan Kanoa in the south, through the long bloody fight in the central mountains around Mount Tapotchao and finally to the last Japanese stand in the north.

Bloody Rock – This is a hypothetical campaign game that lets the players decide how to defend Saipan and how to invade it. The American player receives the same historical forces but now has the opportunity to devise his own landing schedule over one of 25 beaches. The Japanese player gets to prepare his own defenses; set up pillboxes, lay mines and deploy 6” naval guns etc. Can you do better than history?

Complexity: 6

Solitaire Suitability:8

Time Scale: 1 turn = 2 hours

Map Scale: 1 hex = 500 meters

Unit Scale: Companies and below

Players: Best with 2 players but can be played with up to 4 players as well as solitaire

In Metal Dawn, a networked rogue satellite military defense system named Dominus has revolted against its makers, turning its machines of war towards eradicating mankind in a cybernetic revolution. The players are a united faction of agents whose mission is to destroy the forces of the machine while hacking the network to take down the satellite before it’s too late.

In this fast-paced, action-packed, highly replayable cooperative game, 1-4 players make meaningful strategic choices that determine the fate of the world. Players work together to equip their agents, activate zone abilities, and combat the forces of Dominus while collecting intel to crack the code for deactivating the rogue satellite putting a stop to his plan. Once hacked, Dominus is forced to land on Earth and transform into a giant battle robot to face humanity the final showdown. This must all be done before Dominus overruns the world sending it into a chaotic terror and disarray thereby allowing his forces to subjugate and eradicate mankind.

The Little War is a wargame for two players exploring the short but spirited border conflict between Slovakia and Hungary in March, 1939. The action begins on March 23, 1939. The time covered by an entire game may represent 8-12 days, depending on events within the game.

The game lasts 7 turns. In general terms, both players will draw a number of cards from a deck of ordinary playing cards, then will play them alternately one by one to conduct different activities with their counters on the map.

Each game comes with 30 counters, an area-movement map of a portion of eastern Slovakia, and short rules. Players will also need a deck of ordinary playing cards (with 2 Jokers) and several six-sided dice.

Published by Hollandspiele in 2017 as part of a two-game package, together with Ukrainian Crisis: Ukrainian Crisis & The Little War. The games within the box use separate components, and only share a rulebook.

Drop the Puck is a hockey themed board game. Drop the puck has turn based game play. 
On a players turn they take 2 actions with 2 different team members. The turn actions let players move, pass, shoot, steal the puck and perform other hockey related actions. 
The shooting and passing require a player to roll a die and beat a number depending on how far away the shot or pass is and how many opponents are trying to block it. Dice are also used to try and block shots, fight, and attempt penalties. Other actions involve moving team member figures on the board. Players also have cards to play that enhance the actions they take on their turn. After taking their turn the player advances their game clock token to keep track of game length.
After 3 periods of play the player who scored the most goals wins.

Metras is a game for 3-4 players with an approximate duration of 15 minutes per player. You become the head of a Noble Family of the Empire of Metras seeking the favor of Emperor. You will hold lavish parties, resort to intrigue and corruption, or face epic missions on behalf of the Emperor. 
For your Family to succeed, you will have to place and use allies in key positions to hoard Influence Points (IP), a measure of your power at the Imperial Court.
The winner is the Family who earns the most Influence Points.

The game has 5 turns and the players may perform action by buying action card through an auction from the market using the Influence Point, that you need to win, as coins. 
Action cards are the actions that you can do at the Emperor's court. Each action refers to a one of the four branch of the player's Noble family and they relate to specific aspect of the life at Court.

The branches are:

Fame: this branch indicates the direct influence that the family has on the life at the imperial court;
Exploration: this branch indicates the military and exploratory capacity of the family;
Wealth: this branch indicates, in addition to the assets, the organization and the economic grandeur of the family;
Espionage: this branch indicates the capacity and the amount of spies every family has;

To increase the strength of each branch you must recruit allies or servant that will help you do the actions you bought at auction.

Welcome to Panzer Orders, a World War 2 card game. The game is fast and fun to play and takes around 30 mins. The game includes rules for a two player game and separate rules for the solitaire game.

The game contains two decks of cards - one deck for the Allies and one for the Germans. All of the cards have completely unique artwork with no duplicates. Each card has a points value based on the card characteristics and special rules. The players agree a point based battle and then build their decks, spending points on specific cards.

Each player must form three columns of any mixture of vehicles, tanks, or infantry and then attack the opponents columns. The first player to defeat all three columns or force the opposing player to draw their last card, wins the game.

During the player turn you can choose to dig and defend with your card, moves cards from one column to another or attack with long range or close combat. None of these are without their risks and weighing up the risk vs the strategic gain is part of the decision making elements of the game.

Combat is fast, simple but very brutal with all the dice rolls required on the cards - no charts or looking up in the rules. Damaged cards are suppressed first before being removed from the game and can still make a free saving throw on the dice to keep in the fight.

Oh Sh*t! is a card game that is really simple to play and excremely fun!

Even if it's poo, there is an easy unique strategy you must play to survive the longest you can!

Filled with different flavor of poo cards, Oh Sh*t! is a game for having fun in family and friends around a table and is a fast playing game! We are sure you'll like it!

Oh Shit! is a simple and really fun card game where you need to prevent stacking 5 poo cards. You can flush them with a toilet or making a 3 color match on your pile. A suppository will remove only the top card and cancel the constipation.

Anyone can play and it is really fun to fill other players with poo!

Description from the publisher:

1500 - The New World is a board game for 2 to 6 players! Each game sets-up in 10 minutes and plays in under a hour! The fast flowing game play is perfect for casual and serious gamers ages 12 and up!

Each player selects a color for their tokens, and then places their Victory tokens and Royal Support tokens on the map. They also gather their Colony tokens in front of them in preparation for conquest! Set-up concludes with each player receiving their starting cards.

During your turn, you get to play those cards.

Cards can be played for their text. There are two types of cards: Action cards are tan, and you play them during your turn. Reaction cards are red and are played in reaction to other players' playing cards. Each player, on their turn, can play as many Action cards as they are able to.

Every card can also be played to perform one of several basic actions. A card can be played to do any of the following: build a colony, reduce a colony, repair a colony, or adjust Royal Support.

Once you have finished playing cards, you get to tally up your points for the turn. You receive one point for each successful colony you have on the map, and a bonus of two more victory points for each of your export or regional monopolies!

Each of the other players then takes a turn. Once everyone has had a turn, advance the Time Counter.

The game ends when you move the Turn token into the Game Over square. The winner of the game is the player with the most Victory Points!

A smaller-box, shorter variant of Callisto - The Game.

From the Callisto page:
Callisto’s brilliant design, including a board that changes surface according to the number of players present, is among one of the features that make this game so unique. While the goal is simple–to be the first player to place all of his/her tiles onto the board-the shapes of the tiles and additional columns make winning quite tricky. The game plays out like a competitive puzzle, and finesse and cunning are required to triumph.

Differences between Callisto and Callisto - The Game:
- This version has fewer tiles (13 vs the original's 17) in a different distribution
- Instead of the orginal octagonal gameboard this version only offers "frames", therefore no "dark areas" where first tiles cannot be placed and the play area is square
- non-mechanism differences: smaller box, cardboard tiles instead of plastic ones.

Die Lieder, die Nerven is a German board game based on the students' choir Unicante.

Players take on the roles of choir conductors, drafting actions over a course of 24 rounds (placing "helping hands" on the available actions slots). The actions include drawing arrangement cards and placing rehearsal markers on them to collect victory points, but also improving their abilities to get more helping hands, become better at rehearsing etc.

Being the conductor of a large choir can be quite stressful, so keep an eye on your "nerve" ressource.

German introductory text from the booklet

Leite einen Chor durch ein turbulentes Probenjahr. Sammle Arrangements und probe die Stücke. Verbessere die Fähigkeiten deines Chors und deines Teams.
Und vor allem: Nicht die Nerven verlieren!
Dann kannst du am Ende des Chorjahres mit einem Konzert glänzen, das die meisten Siegpunkte wert ist.

Das Spiel wird in einer festgelegten Anzahl von Runden gespielt. Durch das Einstudieren von Arrangements sammeln die Mitspielenden Siegpunkte, was oft Nerven kostet. Ziel des Spiels ist es, am Ende bei den großen Sommernachtskonzerten mehr Siegpunkte als die Mitspieler zu haben. 
In jeder Runde setzen alle nacheinander ihre “Helfenden Hände” auf die Aktionsfelder des Spielplans, um anschließend die entsprechenden Aktionen auszuführen: Neue Arrangements und Proben-Marker zu bekommen, sich mit Fähigkeitsmarkern in den Bereichen Orga, Stimmgruppenleitung und Chorleitung zu verbessern, ihre Teams mit weiteren Helfenden Händen zu vergrößern... und immer ihre Nervenpolster zu pflegen.

Bla5t is a fun and quickly learnt party game in french that combines memory and strategy. It was designed by two authors and one artist from Lausanne (Switzerland) and released in November 2016, after a long year of development.

The game is inspired from an old 56 classic cards game known as Tamalou, Raspoutine or Gabo. It is played in several rounds where the players will avoid cumulating points. Each of them starts with 4 cards face down and looks only at 2. By replacing some of their cards with drawn ones and playing capacities, they will progressively gain knowledge of their game and the ones of their opponents, whom they will steal cards from.

At the end of each round, the players’ scores are marked down and added to the ones of previous rounds. A game ends when one of the players reaches 100 points, the winner being the one who has the least. For a shorter game, a maximum score of 50 points can be set.

The theme is post-apocalyptic, the illustrations being humoristic creatures and heroes inspired by old movies.

Imagine if you could embody a hero character with the power to challenge or otherwise embarrass your friends. But be careful, for those same friends wield powerful item cards that threaten to change the game at any moment! Now combine this with a leveling system to keep it competitive and a damage system to make it vindictive and this is BaRPiG - The unholy result of a one night stand between card-based role-playing games and a mostly ridiculous party.

Gameplay takes place in two alternating rounds: The Challenge Round, followed by the Market Round. During the Challenge round, players compete through challenge, gaining and losing "Drink" and "Sober" points. During the Challenge round, whenever you lose Drink points, take that many ‘drinks’ (eg: sips) from your beverage. If you gain Drink points, you get to choose another player to take that many ‘drinks’.  During the Market round, players buy Items from the market - as long as they have enough in their Bar Tab to cover it. They can also recharge their Bar Tab.

Rounds continue until the first player reaches Level 5 on the their Level card and Wins!

—description from the publisher

From the box

"Biblical Buddies draws both child and adult alike into a land where 20th century meets biblical history. Experience the exciting journey from the Garden of Eden to the Promised Land. Meet Adam and Eve, Noah, Moses, David and Goliath and all the Biblical Buddies characters. Players begin in the Garden of Eden and embark upon an adventure through major events of biblical history including Noah's Ark, David and Goliath, the Parting of the Red Sea and many more. This journey includes both setbacks and rewards with the ultimate goal of reaching the Promised Land."

Biblical Buddies is a roll-and-move game, with each player working towards reaching the end of the track first.  Many spaces on the board have instructions to either help you move forward faster or to go back, lose a turn, etc. As players traverse the board they will read about many different biblical characters. A provided information booklet allows the player to find out more about each character and the role they played in the biblical stories.

June 15th 1983:  NATO fights the fight it was created for and the fate of the Free World hangs in the balance!

Will the Blue Water Navy deliver the convoys desperately needed in Europe or will the Red Banner Northern Fleet smash them at sea, allowing the Red army to steamroller Western Europe?

Blue Water Navy covers the war at sea, air, close-ashore and low-earth orbit from the Kola Peninsula in Northern Russia to the Mediterranean Sea and West over the Atlantic Ocean to the United States and Cuba. The game models the full order of battle that could be expected in 1980’s wartime, from multi-regiment Soviet Tu-22 Backfire bombers to multiple US carrier groups.

The game is card driven, with each card providing points to move units or trigger special events such as ‘KGB Assassinations’ and ‘Space Shuttle’. There is also a reaction mechanic where most cards can be used in the other player’s turn to perform a spoiling event such as ‘Raid Aborts’ and ‘Friendly Fire’.

The heart of the game is detection. Task Forces can only be attacked once detected. By contrast, land air-bases can always be attacked – their enemy knows where they are. The race to detect opposing Task Forces begins as soon as they enter potential striking range of units such as the formidable Soviet bomber formations, or perhaps the Soviet’s submarine fleet which, whilst it has considerable strength, cannot effectively detect enemy forces without help from its comrades.

NATO must not only deliver convoys, but also protect its allies! Norway will be hard pressed, as will Denmark. Both will require urgent reinforcement. In the Mediterranean Sea, Soviet forces must be halted by naval aviation strikes. In the deeper seas, NATO may enact it’s promised attack on the Soviet nuclear deterrent and the Soviets may attempt to respond. Perhaps the Typhoon SSBNs will flee under the Arctic ice to await doomsday, or hole-up in the White Sea. Perhaps the Soviets will use nuclear weapons and scatter those NATO forces that are no-doubt determined to bomb the Soviet’s Kola Peninsula bases.

The game models Politburo approval (Soviet leadership) through a stability mechanism, and whether the Soviets feel they can reduce New York to cinders through the use of ‘First Strike Points’ – these allow the use of things like chemical or nuclear weapons. The game has spies, technological theft, satellites, B-52’s, special forces and Soviet spy trawlers..

Complexity:  6 out of 10 (medium)
Solitaire suitability:  6 out of 10 (medium)
Time Scale: Each turn = 1 day
Map Scale:  Each area represents 500 nautical miles square
Unit Scale:  Each counter represents 10 ships, 3 submarines, one squadron or regiment
Number of Players: 2
Playing Time:  1-3 hours for scenarios and 8-16 hours per campaign game

Components:

    2 map
    4 countersheets: counters are a mix of 1 inch, 5/8″ and ½” markers
    2 decks of 55 playing cards
    6 double-sided player aids
    2 single-sided player aids
    1 rules and scenario booklet
    10 ten-sided dice
    1 box and lid set


(from publisher's website)


The errata file, which is updated as we find them is here https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/2264466/errata-thread

Vassal Module is available here http://www.vassalengine.org/wiki/Module:Blue_Water_Navy

"Sangoku!" is a card game for two people in which the players become monarchs of one country, led by warlords, aiming at unification of the three countries, set in the world of the Chinese Three Kingdoms period.

Each player draws cards from the deck alternately one card at a time and place cards in his hand next to one of the 5 castle cards placed in the field. You can declare "Siege" by arranging 5 cards next to the castle. You can earn a castle if your opponent does not have five cards at his next turn in the siege declaration. However, in case he managed to place five cards in his side of the castle sieged, a decisive battle will be held to win the castle by the stronger combination of cards. A player who wins 3 castles first wins the game.

The discovery of Pearl Lands, a galaxy with abundant resources, changed the face of the space race forever. Fleets traveled to Pearl Lands to transport new red shiny Pearl resource to our solar system, an adventure that was not possible before the use of Pearl extensively in every part of space technology. And the gift of Pearl Lands was not limited to Pearl! A green rain made of grain, discovered on a Pearl Lands’ planet, created a new energy source for space technologies, and a curious little yellow flower with beautiful petals provided Mana, a seed to be cultivated with utmost care. So, with these three new resources previously unknown to mankind, space travel to the farthest points of the Pearl Lands galaxy became a reality, and with the establishment of colony after colony Pearl Lands has become a new home for mankind.

Of course, war has never ended. With the use of new technologies, it just became more sophisticated. Fights for planets turned into a fight for resources, whether by using fire power or trade channels. Prosperity was never enough for mankind. There was always more to gain, and more to develop. Now it's your turn to join the race. Trade, fight and build future technologies. Power is a beautiful thing, so make sure you have it all…

Pearl Lands is a 2-4 player resource management strategy game with a sci-fi theme in which you compete to build three main resource buildings before other players. It’s a fast paced game that gets more and more intense with each passing turn.

The game has different strategy elements like attacking opponents to steal their resources, trading resources and using universe cards to change the course of the game (sometimes just slightly and sometimes drastically). Its combat mechanics is similar to Risk, while trade aspect gives it more like a Catan style strategy element. However there is no tile or troop movement factor that complicate things: it’s designed to be fun and straightforward.

Pearl Lands is full of surprises: the game can turn even at the last round. However it’s not a game of pure luck. The player with long term winning strategy will definitely have the upper hand, and most likely will be the target of other players banding together against her. Alliances are of the utmost importance. Cunning players will find the game to their liking, but utilizing only the art of deception may not be enough to win the game. Sometimes desperate measures like a kamikaze attack to destroy five resource crystals by sacrificing an attack ship can change the balance of power. And buying universe cards can pay off greatly if you get one extra attack or defense die, or get to change the resource setup on the board to sabotage an opponent's game plan.

Description from the publisher:

Don't get fooled by our innocent looking bandits. In their sights are the most precious of art and jewelry the museum has on display. The security systems are no match for their wits; their only obstacle is each other's treachery.

Museum Heist is a subtle game of bluff and deceit in which players assume a hidden identity in an effort to conceal their malicious moves and be the first to grab the museum's prized possessions.

Description from the publisher:

Bring the family together for laugh-out-loud fun with the ridiculous mouthpiece challenge game Speak Out: Kids vs Parents!

During the game, players try to say different phrases while wearing a mouthpiece that won't let them shut their mouth. Parents pick from the Parents deck of cards, filled with phrases parents might say to kids such as "This playroom is a positive pigsty!" Kids get to choose from the Kids deck filled with things kids might say such as "What a bummer, brother." Players read the phrase as best as they can to their teammates, but it's not so easy to do as the timer counts down and the mouthpiece is hindering them from forming words correctly. The laughter continues as players try to decipher what in the world their teammate is trying to say, and must correctly guess the phrase in order to earn the card. The team with the most cards at the end of the game wins.
